componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Dow Chemical Company's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Also, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Neal Sheorey, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Dow Chemical Company's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. I am Neal Sheorey, Vice President of Investor Relations. As usual, we are making this call available to investors and the media via webcast. This call is a pr
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Dow Chemical Company's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. I am Neal Sheorey, Vice President of Investor Relations. As usual, we are making this call available to investors and the media via webcast. This call is a property of The Dow Chemical Company. Any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without Dow's expressed written consent is strictly prohibited. 
On the call with me today are Andrew Liveris, Dow's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Howard Ungerleider, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; and Jim Fitterling, President and Chief Operating Officer. 
We have prepared slides to supplement our comments in this conference call. These slides are posted on our Investor Relations financial reporting webpage. You can also access the slides through the link to our webcast. 
I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in both the press release and in the slides. In summary, it says that statements in the press release, the presentation and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the safe harbor provision under Federal Securities Laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we describe in our filings with the SEC. 
In addition, some of our comments represent not GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure and other associated disclosures are contained in our earnings release and on our website. Unless otherwise specified, all comparisons presented today will be on a year-over-year basis. Sales comparisons exclude divestitures and acquisitions. EBITDA, EBITDA margins, return on capital and earnings comparisons exclude certain items. 
I will now turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neal. If you turn to Slide 3, and good morning, everyone. Let me open the review of the quarter by stepping back and just looking at our 3 simple and very focused goals of the year: first one, achieve our plans; Second one, close Dow Corning
componenttext:
Thank you, Neal. If you turn to Slide 3, and good morning, everyone. 
Let me open the review of the quarter by stepping back and just looking at our 3 simple and very focused goals of the year: first one, achieve our plans; Second one, close Dow Corning by mid-year; and third, drive the merger milestones with DuPont for a year-end close. Simple, clear, and focused. 
Let's start with the plan. Dow's relentless and disciplined execution once again delivered another quarter of operating earnings growth and margin expansion. And the Dow team has again done it through a variety of challenge and geopolitical and market conditions and outpacing our peers in the process. You can see that in our results, 15 consecutive quarters of earnings growth and margin expansion, 11 consecutive quarters of volume growth. Notably, we delivered gains in all geographies, with particular strength in the United States, China and Europe. Cash flow from operations of $2.2 billion, up nearly 60% versus the year-ago period. 
We are focused on every aspect of the P&L and balance sheet to deliver these numbers with weekly operations meanings and very strong self-help actions. Our unique combination of world-class innovation, diversified integration and a narrow and deeper market focus enabled operating earnings growth in every business in our Consumer Solutions and Infrastructure Solutions segments, while the strength of our Plastics franchise was again on display. 
We have built our portfolio to grow both the top and bottom line, even though market and economic conditions remained challenging. In those markets that are challenged, we have been implementing proactive and targeted self-help measures. You can see this in our Ag segment, where our actions have generated earnings year-to-date that have outperformed the industry downturn. Another example is our recent restructuring announcement related to the Dow Corning transaction, which will reduce headcount by an additional 700 positions on top of the Dow Corning synergies to a total of 2,500 and accelerated earnings growth under these volatile market conditions. Howard will review our results in more granularity in a moment, but the income and cash flow results are truly noteworthy. 
Our second goal is, indeed, to close Dow Corning and its ownership restructuring, where we're bringing a new element for growth and technology platform that will to further drive Dow's focus and an attractive targeted market segments as well as enhance the earnings power of the new Dow. Soon after closing, we will also increase our cost synergy target by $100 million to $400 million. When combined with the estimated $100 million of growth synergies, we see a total of $500 million of synergies from this transaction. We achieved this goal ahead of schedule on June 1, and I'm happy to report that the integration has proceeded seamlessly. 
And on our third goal, we recently received overwhelming approval with the historic DowDuPont transaction from our shareholders, illustrating the market's recognition of this unique opportunity to deliver value to all stakeholders as we drive the intended separation into 3 independent, leading size-based [ph] companies that will redefine their respective industries. Simply put, the Dow team is sharply focused on driving our 3 goals, and this quarter's report shows the results of this effort. 
I'll now turn the call over to Howard to cover highlights from the quarter and an update on Dow Corning. Jim will then give an update on our Plastics franchise and DowDuPont. And I'll close with our outlook and earnings growth drivers. Howard?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. Good morning, everyone. On Slide 5, Dow's financial performance had several noteworthy highlights in the second quarter. The team delivered operating EPS of $0.95 a share despite the slow growth and certain macroeconomic environment. The D
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. Good morning, everyone. On Slide 5, Dow's financial performance had several noteworthy highlights in the second quarter. The team delivered operating EPS of $0.95 a share despite the slow growth and certain macroeconomic environment. The Dow team found pockets of growth in all of our major geographies, and we kept our focus on driving further productivity gains, adding another $90 million of savings in the quarter, bringing our first half savings to $180 million, tracking well above our 2016 target of $300 million. 
Our innovative products and solutions are also winning in the marketplace. Many of our businesses highlighted market share gains and new business wins, as evidenced by our continued volume and margin growth in the quarter. Our overall operating EBITDA margin rose more than 160 basis points to 21%, our highest second quarter margin in a decade, led by gains in Consumer and Infrastructure Solutions and Performance Plastics. 
We also achieved multiple records in the quarter, including EBITDA records in Consumer Solutions, Infrastructure Solutions and Performance Plastics and the sales volume record in Performance Plastics, all of which helped the team deliver an $800 million increase in cash flow from operations in the quarter.
Taking a longer view, the progress we've made over the past 4 years has enabled us to significantly grow EPS above our target of 10% annual growth. They continue to increase free cash flow generation while fueling our future growth through targeted investments and, at the same time, return $14 billion through our shareholders through share buybacks and paid dividends. 
Now turning to our segment results on Slide 6. Let's start with Ag. We're delivering despite high industry Crop Protection inventories, currency headwinds and low crop commodity prices. Our Ag team continues to respond with targeted self-help actions that have largely offset the headwinds while maintaining the long-term growth potential of our franchise. In the second quarter, we achieved double-digit sales growth in corn seeds, but that was more than offset by soft demand in sunflower and soybeans. Crop Protection volume was lower, primarily due to reduced generic herbicide demand and the impact of the AgroFresh divestiture. 
For the year, we see the market declining 5% on robust deals in North America, high inventories and low crop prices. In the second half of 2016, Crop Protection volume is expected to be flat, with modest pricing pressure due to lower demand for insecticides and generic herbicides, and we expect some positives in seeds, as the Latin America season outlook improves. 
On Slide 7, Consumer Solutions continues to deliver impressive results, achieving record EBITDA of $341 million. Earnings increased in all businesses on market share gains, new business wins and robust demand for our innovative products.
Dow Automotive achieved record second quarter EBITDA and double-digit volume growth, driven by strong demand for light-weighting and sound dampening technologies and benefited from greater production of SUVs and trucks, which contained more Dow content. 
Consumer Care recorded higher earnings, led by double-digit volume growth in personal care applications, solid demand in home core sectors and market share gains. 
Dow Electronic Materials delivered double-digit EBITDA growth on share gains in the semiconductor and display end markets. 
And our newly integrated Consumer Solutions silicones business captured greater market share on strong demand in the consumer care sector, notably, in Europe and Asia Pacific. 
On Slide 8, Infrastructure Solutions also reported EBITDA growth in every business. Dow Building and Construction delivered a record quarterly EBITDA and saw a volume growth in most geographies on strong demand for its construction chemicals, spray foam insulation and continued adoption of our blue edge technology. 
In Energy and Water Solutions, self-help actions mitigated persistent energy headwinds as oil and gas exploration project demand remains low. Water fundamentals, however, remained robust. Our new Saudi RO membrane plant is at full rates, positioning us well to meet demand in emerging geographies. 
We also saw improvement in Performance Monomers, reflecting our aggressive self-help measures, including our purposeful reduction in merchant sales exposure. 
Dow Coating Materials grew volume in all sectors, and our new vinyl acrylic binders are enabling share gains and diversification into value-add applications. 
Finally, our new Infrastructure Solutions Silicones business saw strong demand in the construction sector, enabling higher first half EBITDA. 
On Slide 9, Performance Materials & Chemicals had several moving parts in the quarter. Equity earnings were over $100 million lower, consistent with our modeling guidance, due to the change in ownership of MEGlobal, coupled with lower energy prices and Sadara startup costs. 
When you take into account these 2 items, the core Polyurethanes business performed well, as it continued to increasingly tilt for its higher-value specialty portfolio. The business delivered double-digit volume growth in its systems houses on strong consumer demand, particularly in Asia Pacific, enabled by our new polyols plant in Thailand. This benefit, however, was offset by margin compression in the upstream portion of the business, where supply balances have loosened and turnaround and maintenance costs were higher due to planned outage in Europe and a short unplanned outage in Brazil. 
And Industrial Solutions, putting the impacts on equity earnings to one side, our core business delivered flat earnings, as disciplined self-help actions offset challenging industrial end market conditions. 
Turning to Performance Plastics on Slide 10. Reported record second quarter EBITDA with volume gains across most businesses in all geographies. Packaging and Specialty Plastics achieved several second quarter records, including EBITDA and sales volume, enabled by operational excellence, reflecting an aligned team focused on manufacturing reliability and producing incremental volume in a robust demand environment. Additionally, the business recovered margin in Latin America on demand and growth. 
Dow Elastomers volume increases from strong demand for its innovative technologies in automotive, hot-melt adhesives and athletic footwear were balanced by the impact of production from a higher turnaround activity in the quarter. 
Dow Electronics -- Electrical and Telecommunications delivered volume growth across all geographies, led by double-digit gains in the Americas on continued demand for fiber optic, coax and jacketing solutions. 
Turning now to Slide 12. As Andrew stated, our teams successfully closed to the ownership addressing of Dow Corning in June. As we worked together more closely with the Dow Corning team, we discovered even more opportunities to streamline, giving us the confidence to increase our cost synergy target by $100 million to $400 million, with 1,800 role reductions directly related to Dow Corning. We expect to achieve a 70% run rate within 12 months of closing and the full cost synergy run rate within 24 months. The growth synergies of $100 million will be captured within 36 months. This transaction will unlock significant value for Dow shareholders, and it is expected to be accretive to our EPS, operating cash flow and free cash flow in year 1. And at full synergy run rate, it is expected to add greater than $1 billion of EBITDA to our bottom line. 
Finally, in order to leave ample time for Q&A at the end of the call, we have included our usual modeling guidance slide in the appendix of the deck. 
I'll now turn it over to Jim.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. I'll start with [indiscernible] growth lever, our Plastics franchise. The dynamics across the polyethylene chain can shift significantly over time and is critical to remain agile and adaptive with this industry. The long-term winters
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. I'll start with [indiscernible] growth lever, our Plastics franchise. 
The dynamics across the polyethylene chain can shift significantly over time and is critical to remain agile and adaptive with this industry. The long-term winters are the players that own the entire chain integration and can manage the swings through feedstock flexibility, diversification and differentiation and global reach. And our results have shown that Dow does this exceptionally well time and time again, maximizing our returns while reducing our long-term earnings volatility. As value in the chain shifts over time, our direct-to-customer intimacy, innovation and application development and technical support differentiate our earnings unlike all of our competitors. 
On Slide 15, I'll go through our polyethylene view. Consistent with the view that we've held since the beginning of the year, we see polyethylene balances remaining stable over the next few years. Demand growth continues globally, as consumers expect higher food safety standards, better sustainability at plastic packaging relative to the alternatives and improvements in packaging functionality and convenience that polyethylene provides. On the ethylene supply side, our view takes into account that the leading industry consultants forecast capacity additions that overstate what actually gets built. We saw this play out just a few years ago. 
And we think that incremental delays and project postponements will happen once again. In fact, we've already seen evidence of this. 
We believe that both ethylene and polyethylene rates will remain high globally, and we continue to expect higher operating rates in polyethylene than in ethylene. And as we seen this year, there may be some regional differences. 
Earlier this year, some called for a very weak condition in the second half of the year. We did not hold that view. And today, margins remain a firm globally, and inventories are below average. I will state once again that we see continuing good conditions with expected seasonality over the next few years. 
In this environment, the Sadara additions will position us well to capture growth where growth exists. That 26 units at this worldscale facility, the largest of its kind ever built in a single phase, continue to come online. We're in a ramp and startup activity right now. We have qualified 25 polyethylene products to date and have shipped polyethylene from the first 2 trains to nearly 100 customers in more than 25 countries. The multi-feed cracker is now in the early phases of startup, and we expect commercial operation in the third quarter. All construction at the Sadara site should be completed by year-end, with commissioning thereafter. We are happy with the progress made to date and will continue to provide updates as we get closer to year-end. 
I'll leave my comments with DowDuPont on Slide 16. We continue to make significant progress on the transaction and the pursuit of the intended separation into 3 independent publicly traded companies. All key deliverables remain on track, and just last week, both companies received overwhelming support from our respective shareholders to approve the merger. We continue to focus on preparations for day 1, developing the financials for the intended spend and also driving the regulatory approval process. As I've said before, the vast majority of Dow people are focused on day-to-day business results, and our teams are doing a great job of making sure these transactions do not take away from our sharp focus to deliver the 2016 financial plan. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Andrew for our outlook and earnings drivers.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Thank you, Jim. If you turn to Slide 18. Our earnings growth drivers are very visible to us, clearly definable and will be appearing in our bottom line results over these next few years. Just to remind you, from 2012 to 2015, Dow has delivered an
componenttext:
Good. Thank you, Jim. If you turn to Slide 18. 
Our earnings growth drivers are very visible to us, clearly definable and will be appearing in our bottom line results over these next few years. Just to remind you, from 2012 to 2015, Dow has delivered an EPS growth CAGR of 22% per year based on an intervention mindset on productivity and portfolio management, aggressive self-help actions, if you like. During this time, our R&D and innovation agenda delivered new products and technologies and upgrading our margin from 13% to 20% in the same period and growing core volumes on average 2% per year. As you can see from this quarter's results, we are at a $10 billion EBITDA run rate. Building from 2015's results and adding our specific actions, interventions and projects, we grow the new Dow's EBITDA post [indiscernible] spin to greater than $15 billion of EBITDA and 25% EBITDA margin. You can see here what we count: productivity premerger; the U.S. Gulf Coast and Sadara investments at steady run rate; the Dow Corning transaction; and the Dow DuPont transaction, which are materials synergy targets of $1.5 billion; plus Dow's Performance Materials business, minus Dow's Agricultural Sciences and Electronic Materials business. Note that we do not count any growth synergies, any market organic growth or any new innovation contribution. These new earnings streams are in motion and are known to us and described to you. And we will do all of this in a market and global economy that is mixed at best. Our outlook is that this won't change. Volatility and macro uncertainties are the new norm. But Dow will deliver, as it has these many years, by firmly executing against our earnings growth drivers. And we will continue to grow earnings before, during and after the merger and its intended spins. We have the team to do so. We have not been, nor will we be, distracted in delivering value for our shareholders. 
And with that, Neal, let's turn to Q&A.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I just want to get your thoughts on ethylene and polyethylene in the next, I guess, 2 quarters. We have seen potentially some turnarounds here in the first half, and some of those are potentially moderating here in the second half. What's your ou
componenttext: I guess, I just want to get your thoughts on ethylene and polyethylene in the next, I guess, 2 quarters. We have seen potentially some turnarounds here in the first half, and some of those are potentially moderating here in the second half. What's your outlook for pricing in polyethylene over the next quarter or 2? Do you expect some moderation in pricing in the third quarter and fourth quarter as you -- as operating rates kind of tick down?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Jim.
componenttext: Go ahead, Jim.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Arun. Look, every -- Plastic's story, I think, is still demand. And demand has been strong, and our volume growth, the 13%, reflects that. In fact, we had growth in all geographic areas, especially EMEA and Asia Pacific and also, this year, in Lat
componenttext: Thanks, Arun. Look, every -- Plastic's story, I think, is still demand. And demand has been strong, and our volume growth, the 13%, reflects that. In fact, we had growth in all geographic areas, especially EMEA and Asia Pacific and also, this year, in Latin America. So hopeful that we're seeing a rebound in the developing economies right now. And our operating EBITDA is up 7% versus same quarter last year. Compared to previous quarter, pricing is up. Compared to same quarter last year, pricing's off [ph] about $0.01. So I think you're seeing that reflected, the polyethylene price reflects that robust demand. And then my point on inventories, I mean, the derivative demand is much tighter than the ethylene demand, and we think that's going to remain the case. And in fact, we continue to see announcements of projects light out of the pipeline. I reflected that in my comments. We continue to see delays forecasted, later start-ups, projects being completely taken out of the forecast for ethylene. But I think, to your point, about back half of the year, I think you're going to see more of the same than you have seen. We see a little bit of seasonality toward the end of the year, typically. But usually, third quarter's a strong quarter for us in Plastic franchise.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just jump on real quickly, Jim. Just the way you think about the way we put the 2 slides in the deck for this reason, the way Jim just described it, is we are #1 in this game, and we understand supply/demand on the ground. When Iran was talked
componenttext: If I could just jump on real quickly, Jim. Just the way you think about the way we put the 2 slides in the deck for this reason, the way Jim just described it, is we are #1 in this game, and we understand supply/demand on the ground. When Iran was talked about 5 years ago, people like nearly consultants had statements, that never happened. We knew what was going on with supply side. So I think the way Jim and all of us are talking about this is these next many years, the delays are going to create the conditions that we've just seen these last few years. We can make money in this chain very nicely, thank you very much, based on demand drivers in supply drivers being in the right place, plus a differentiation. Post-2020, there might be a few more start-ups that I don't think many of you are modeling 2020. So let's work on understanding that dynamic right now is quite favorable.

componenttext: Maybe as you had talked about the Americas creating volume where North American export more to Latin America. But as Latin America demand remains weak, where do you think your volume will to go to balance the market? And just secondly, on your polyethylene or ethylene plant, is your plant on time?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: P.J., thanks for the question. Our demand in Latin America is actually up 4% in the quarter. So we see pretty strong volumes in Latin America. And I think we're going to continue to see Latin America come back. Obviously, the impact of the lower GDP has a
componenttext: P.J., thanks for the question. Our demand in Latin America is actually up 4% in the quarter. So we see pretty strong volumes in Latin America. And I think we're going to continue to see Latin America come back. Obviously, the impact of the lower GDP has a little bit of a market sentimental impact on what happens with the consumer market. But when you look at the currency impacts in Latin America and, for that matter, in most of the developing world, most of the inflationary impacts, as those currency changes, have already been felt. And that's, I think, what leads into our comments that, we think, in the emerging geographies, we're seeing a bottom and, hopefully, a recovery from this point on. Meanwhile, the United States, given the energy feedstock competitiveness, is still one of the lowest-cost places in the world to make these products. And so we still have the ability to export based on our global reach to all parts of the world. And based on the fact that w are focusing on the higher-value end markets, where most of the new capacity is coming on in the really highly commoditized segment, it gives us the added benefit of the power of innovation. So when you look at that power of innovation and the competitiveness of scale that we have, I think we're well positioned to take advantage of this whole market situation. Relative to your point on our timing, our Sadara plants are up, and the cracker is in the startup phase right now. In fact, the systems are running. And we're in the phase right before you really bring on the rest of the furnaces. We got things inventoried in the hydrocarbons units, and we're drying out the rest of the plant and getting ready to go. So you're going to see polyethylene running here. And our hope is that polyethylene turns favorable, more of a tailwind for the plastics business in the back half of the year. U.S. Gulf Coast, the cracker project is making tremendous progress. I think we're well above the 70% completion rate. And as we said, we're going to have that up by mid next year. And the polyethylene plants are coming along very nicely. I was just down in [indiscernible] last month, and I've been down at Texas the last couple of months. And we're making tremendous progress on those. So I think our timing is very consistent with every previous report we've given you on those plants.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next moved to Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And next moved to Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, I was wondering if I could ask you untrained. And in this presidential election, there's an awful lot of back-and-forth about trade policy, whether it's TPP or China or what have you. As you think about that sort of environment over the next coupl
componenttext: Andrew, I was wondering if I could ask you untrained. And in this presidential election, there's an awful lot of back-and-forth about trade policy, whether it's TPP or China or what have you. As you think about that sort of environment over the next couple of years, you think about Dow's business, is there anything that we can discuss right now that's concerning to you at all?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, there's a lot being discussed or not discussed that's concerning but you all know the season you're in. So when we get to the next administration and we engage, we'll engage on all the things that matter to the company, notably, trade. Just a little
componenttext: Look, there's a lot being discussed or not discussed that's concerning but you all know the season you're in. So when we get to the next administration and we engage, we'll engage on all the things that matter to the company, notably, trade. Just a little reminder because I've been asked this question a few times, just a little reminder that the United States has actually put in very few trade agreements in the last 10 years, actually, 3 specific bilats and one multi-lats in the works but not yet done. So I will tell you we haven't really been exposed to the positives of trade, and most of it is because the way Jim answered the other question, which is we're on the ground pretty much everywhere else. And so regionalization, the sum of all places you're in, which is 37 countries for Dow. We're on the ground with physical facility in 37 countries means we have a local market access under all sorts of trade environments. And there are a great trade agreements going on between Asian countries and European Union and elsewhere. So we benefit from all of those. I would like to see the U.S. get to a multi-lat trade agreement, TPP, but we're not counting on it. I think what we're going to see here is a lot of uncertainties in the political environment. And I grew up in Asia, where there were trade barriers everywhere. So Dow has the strategy to operate and generate profit in economies that grow wherever there is growth. And we have the diversification of geographic mix to take a few countries being on the Dow side growth, i.e, like Brazil right now, and of course, manage the upside and like the U.S. and China right now. So I'm not particularly concerned about the rhetoric that's going on right now.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, thank you for the question. I'll take the first little piece of that, and I'll pass it over to Jim. Look, I'm very proud of Dow Automotive and other transportation platform in general. It's a great example of entire company. Steve Henderson and his t
componenttext: Bob, thank you for the question. I'll take the first little piece of that, and I'll pass it over to Jim. Look, I'm very proud of Dow Automotive and other transportation platform in general. It's a great example of entire company. Steve Henderson and his team, in the last 10 years, has changed the mix. So the answer your question, yes. It's a change in mix, changing technology platforms, change in product mix and a change in positioning with the OEMs, both geographic repositioning as well as particularly where you are in the supply chain. And we are speaking to light-weighting, and we're speaking to fuel efficiency. And we are speaking to value-add in the car or in the truck or whatever. So we've got a lot of good programs. Jim, you might want to reference a couple.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob. It's a great question. And look, we still believe that automotive this year is going to have a production level that's above last year even if it's just slightly above, and sales continue to be strong there. We've always had the leading supply i
componenttext: Yes, Bob. It's a great question. And look, we still believe that automotive this year is going to have a production level that's above last year even if it's just slightly above, and sales continue to be strong there. We've always had the leading supply in glass binding. So that business continues to perform exceptionally well. And the addition of crash durable adhesives, I can't underestimate how much of a growth driver that is for this business. Not just in -- I mean, we've highlighted our experience with Ford in the F150, where we're bonding aluminum to a steel structure. And not just light-weighting the vehicle, but improving the crash safety rating of that vehicle, a class of vehicles, is not known for high crash safety ratings. But that applies in other dissimilar materials or whether you're talking about carbon fiber composites on a steel frame, that application still applies. And as we continue to see others focus on light-weighting and our driving force in automotive has been and continues to be free cash flow of the design table with this brand owners. Though we can actually get out there and get our products they tend. We're continuing to see strong growth drivers in those businesses. And that is before we even think about what we can do with the power of Dow Corning's silicones in the mix.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, I appreciate the question because our team is very, very focused, and they've been doing a heck of a job. And I mean that right out to operations and manufacturing. This year, year-to-date, at virtually the same operating rates as we had last year,
componenttext: Frank, I appreciate the question because our team is very, very focused, and they've been doing a heck of a job. And I mean that right out to operations and manufacturing. This year, year-to-date, at virtually the same operating rates as we had last year, we produced 2 billion pounds more production out of our assets. Now 25% of that is PDH. So take that out of the equation. This quarter, we produced 1 billion pounds more out of the same asset base. And so we -- this is Dow's DNA. This is what we do best and what we've always done, and I call the competitiveness and scale, getting that extra percent out of the machine, doing it reliably, doing it safely, working the product mix, working the product waterfalls. Nobody does that better than we do, and the team is firing on all cylinders right now and really looking forward to 2 trains of Sadara being up in this back half of the year because customers are ready for that product.

componenttextpreview: Two questions. My understanding is your PDH unit has had difficulties in producing since you brought it  on stream. Can you talk about what those difficulties are and when they might be remedied? And in terms of your Texas-9 project that you say will be c
componenttext: Two questions. My understanding is your PDH unit has had difficulties in producing since you brought it  on stream. Can you talk about what those difficulties are and when they might be remedied? And in terms of your Texas-9 project that you say will be complete mid-year next year, do you mean mechanically complete? That is, when do you expect to be producing commercially?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Jim. Take both.
componenttext: Go ahead, Jim. Take both.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, that's a good question on PDH. And you'll recall that we did get that plant up in December and got it up in record time. And as I just mentioned on Frank's question, we produced over 500 million pounds of propylene out of that unit this year. The te
componenttext: Jeff, that's a good question on PDH. And you'll recall that we did get that plant up in December and got it up in record time. And as I just mentioned on Frank's question, we produced over 500 million pounds of propylene out of that unit this year. The technology itself is working very well. The catalyst, the reactive performance, strong. In fact, the conversion rates are higher than we expected out of the catalyst. So that all looks good. We had 2 operation, unit operation units inside a plan that gave us some trouble, one heat exchanger, which we referred to earlier this year. And then we just had a problem with a drier bed in the unit where we had to make some mechanical improvements in there. I don't think any of those are fundamental long-term problems. I think they are just the normal problems of startup of a massive units, and those of you who've been down there have seen the size of that thing. So we've got vendors and our support from UOP all over it. And we're expected to be up next week, the week of August 8, and it's looking good right now. So we're very hopeful, the teams are very hopeful that we not only solved a couple of mechanical problems but made a couple of improvement along the way.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on Texas-9, we're mechanically complete in a year. You're going to be mechanically complete on Texas-9, again, in the second quarter next year, and of course, you got to do the commissioning and startup and that takes you usually that are part of
componenttext: And just on Texas-9, we're mechanically complete in a year. You're going to be mechanically complete on Texas-9, again, in the second quarter next year, and of course, you got to do the commissioning and startup and that takes you usually that are part of the quarter to get it up and running. So we're right on schedule with operational by mid-year next year, Jeff.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Peter, the last slide in the deck, which I went through, was to give you guys a great visibility, the way we're thinking about your question, which is as we put together these historic transactions, the Dow Corning one just closed. And of course, you're s
componenttext: Peter, the last slide in the deck, which I went through, was to give you guys a great visibility, the way we're thinking about your question, which is as we put together these historic transactions, the Dow Corning one just closed. And of course, you're seeing a little bit of a positive effect of that already, and our synergy increase there is our confidence of delivering against EBITDA that's in the deck and also as part of the deck. The DowDuPont transaction, the 2 becoming 3 powerful companies based on the synergies that we'll get as well as the complementarity and the growth vehicles that we created material science, agricultural science and specialties. I know you heard it the other day. We're working pedal to the metal to get those metrics in place, the milestones in place, the board reviews and the way we'll run this -- the merge companies with advisory committees. All those metrics, where line to implement speed to close, speed to energy, speed to spin. And those details, granular details, with a powerful shareholder approval we got last week, over 97% of approval in our case and in DuPont's case, this is just an indicator. This is a lot of EBITDA that's, come at both the merged company and then the split -- the intended spins. And we give you a roadmap to the new Dow material science company on that last slide, which shows you 25% EBITDA margin greater than $15 million.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I'd say, right, we typically tend to look at 2 things. Obviously, where are you going to have the low cost feedstocks. And so places like the United States certainly, the Middle East, Canada potentially, Argentina potentially, are all locations whe
componenttext: David, I'd say, right, we typically tend to look at 2 things. Obviously, where are you going to have the low cost feedstocks. And so places like the United States certainly, the Middle East, Canada potentially, Argentina potentially, are all locations where you're going to have access to low-cost feedstocks. And the good news for us is we're on all of those places and we have the ability to expand in all those places and intercept some of that's very incremental for us. Though, certainly, in Canada and the U.S. Gulf Coast, we have opportunities for increment. And then we have the footprint in all of those places to be able to do something full scale if that's what we decide to do. Right now, we have a lot of coming at us over these next few years, and we want to make sure that we take best advantage of the investment that we already made.

componenttext: I was waiting for the first Ag question. On ENLIST, in the approval in China, we continue to wait the approval, import approval for the ENLIST corn freight in China. We believe we provided everything to the Ministry of Agriculture with all the data that they have requested. So we can't tell you when, but technically, with all the data, we believe we are ready to receive the approval. In terms of your ENLIST license question, so look, on corn, Monsanto has a nonexclusive royalty bearing license to access Dow scorn trades. On soybean, the plant that's utilized our own channel and other soybean seed companies both in the U.S. and Latin America. And we're partnering with the strong regional companies, both in the U.S. and Latin America. And with cotton, we're going to marketed the dance brands. So cited in, that accounts -- cotton accounts for 10% of the ENLIST acres that we're projecting. So full speed ahead but we are waiting for the China approval.

componenttext: Yes. I will just say, Steve, we feel very good about the ENLIST technology platform. Remember, it's both the seed as well as the over-the-top ENLIST dual herbicide. And when you do that combination, our view on the herbicide ENLIST duo, we have reduced volatility and reduced drift. So we feel -- and all the trials, all the feedforward trials that we've done in the U.S. and Canada have proven that out on top of all the test costs that we have done internally within Dow Ag. So we feel very good about that.

componenttext: You gave a lot of helpful guidance on the slide in the back around Dow Corning, but I was wondering if you could kind of help quarterly, just because as we analyze this the first year, we don't have good year-over-year data for it. That $800 million and some of the synergies that went through, how will that impact quarterly in Q3 and Q4?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll give the second quarter look on Dow Corning, Duffy, and thanks for the question. In the second quarter, the Dow Corning on the EBITDA line was about $100 million tailwind. Now that included a little bit of purchasing step-up related activities, so yo
componenttext: I'll give the second quarter look on Dow Corning, Duffy, and thanks for the question. In the second quarter, the Dow Corning on the EBITDA line was about $100 million tailwind. Now that included a little bit of purchasing step-up related activities, so you can't take that enrollment through the fall back half of the year. I would say, remember, though, all of our divestitures that we had through the last year. So there was about $100 million of headwind on divestitures. So those pretty much offset each other. On the EPS line in the second quarter, Dow Corning was about a $0.02 EPS tailwind because you take that $100 million, you have to raise -- we borrowed additional money to fund the deal, so you got a higher interest cost. And then of course, you got purchase step-up accounting as well that's a little bit of an offset. So on the EPS line, it was a $0.02 headwind -- a tailwind, excuse me, for us in the second quarter.

componenttext: I'll let Jim [indiscernible]. I just wanted to say something earlier, which has given me the opportunity to repeat what he said and then double down. So Howard and I made a trip out there just this last weekend, and we had a through review of the project team. Jim's on the board and get the need for Dow and that board. The new energy minister, held to your [indiscernible] Aramco was present for a whole day. We are into the granular detail of starting up 25 units all in parallel. And many of them is over 500 Dow people on the site to assist the local Saudis and getting up and running. Very impressive of the quality that starting work force, by the way. It's first class. We've trained them around the world, there are great and we've got the Human Resources on the ground and of course, went out working on the most important one of them all, which is getting the mixed-feed cracker up and running, and then Jim made a comment on that. Actually, they fared ethane in while we were there for the first time. And not often that you want to see the ground play burning ethylene, but everyone was celebrating the burning of ethylene to the ground of what -- that's just a little piece of detail for you. And that you know there's real things happen on that site. Now the handoffs, the multistage handoffs. The fact that there are a loving most of this year all of next year to get these items before we are all the way done. This going to be a lot of those handoffs on either phases. So Jim, you may want to comment on the complexity and what we expect.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So as soon as this cracker comes up, we got the 2P plants ready to run, and then the third plant will be ready to run before the end of the year. So that'll consume quite a bit of ethylene. And then EOM and PO derivatives come on next, and they're
componenttext: Right. So as soon as this cracker comes up, we got the 2P plants ready to run, and then the third plant will be ready to run before the end of the year. So that'll consume quite a bit of ethylene. And then EOM and PO derivatives come on next, and they're going to be complete in the third quarter, beginning of fourth quarter. They have a startup phase to go through, and so you can expect to see them in the first quarter of '17. And then as we go down the aromatics chain, you'll start to see isocyanates and some of the other derivatives come on by mid-next year. So throughout the end of this year, and through most of next year, we're going to be sequentially starting up these units and this integrated complex bring the whole thing up and running. Right now, construction is 99.5% complete. So mechanical completions, every week, we're handing over units to the project team and the operations team. So we're looking good shape to get it up and running. Your point on tailwind, our view is still you got to see equity earnings out of Sadara of $400 million to $500 million in that time frame when they're all up and running.

componenttext: Yes, Jonas, I would say, yes, we're going to be synchronized in our stock buyback, right? So we've been, as you know, well until the shareholder vote, we've been required to be out of the market. So we're very pleased that Andrew talked about the shareholder vote earlier in the call. So we're pleased to that's behind us. So right now, we're not going to do any kind of an ASR. We're going to go open-market purchases. So we obviously -- the next step is we need to treat due to the open. As soon as the  trading window opens, we do intend to fully to buy back stock but within the volume limits that we have. And obviously, in the summer months, the volume tends to be a little bit light. But we intend to buy as much as we possibly can, in sync with DuPont, in line with the volume.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, look, we've been aggressive in reducing costs. The long-term growth drivers in the business are robust, right? I mean, population growth, limited [indiscernible], urbanization, water scarcity. I mean, you known, Dawn, better than probably anybody on this call why we feel so good about the Ag market. I would say we still believe that the market overall is going to decline 5%, but our team, the Dow Ag team, have really been focus on accommodation of productivity self-help as well as introduction of new molecules on the Crop Protection side as well as growing as much as we can, as quickly as we can on the seed front. So we feel good about the back half. I mean, it's still going to be a tough -- still a tough Ag macro. You talked a little bit about some of the potential headwind move and the tailwind in Latin America, and I would agree with that. Our goal is to outperform the competition. That's what the team is focused on.

componenttext: Andrew, a bunch of questions, obviously, on ethylene, polyethylene supply demand fundamentals. Jim allude sort of this point earlier in the call that over the last couple of months, we've sort of seen and heard a fair degree of cynicism around ethylene supply demand fundamentals. But part and parcel with that cynicism is the feedstock side of things as well. There seems to be the perception that ethane is going to get tight very quickly. And I've heard numbers like $0.50 to $0.60 a gallon eminently being thrown around. Now we clearly have a slight in the deck talking about your views on ethane being launched. So A, would love for you to talk a bit about why you feel ethane is going to be long; and B, what sort of energy pricing stack are you using when you're coming up with your ethane supply/demand sort of analysis?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. I think it's a very good question, Hassan, and it's the reason we put that in the back of the deck. I'm glad you looked at that. I think, a couple of things. Obviously, on the demand side for ethane, my comments about what's happening with project
componenttext: Thanks. I think it's a very good question, Hassan, and it's the reason we put that in the back of the deck. I'm glad you looked at that. I think, a couple of things. Obviously, on the demand side for ethane, my comments about what's happening with project delays and things sliding, the timing impact a little bit of that demand picture. But the power of feedstock flexibility here is what we always talk about in Dow. And one of the reasons we invest the way that we do is propane and natural play a big role in this 2. So propane right now is capping ethane and the other dynamic that you see happening is that probe and exports out of the U.S. are really flooding and exhausting some of the available buyers that are in that market. And natural gas prices are low. And the supply, even with the rig counts down, the supply has continued to be very strong. And now we're starting to see recounts pick up a little bit. So our view here is that despite the exports, despite all the other things happening, you're still going to be long propane and ethane. And you're going to be longer in that gas and propane than you are ethane. And when you're long propane and propanes in the crack slate, that's advantaged out. And so that's what we play for. Obviously, we have the flexibility to go back and ethane when that's possible. But look, there's more gas supply at low cost that coming on every day, not just in the U.S It's coming on in the Middle East. It's in Australia. It's putting pressure on these gas prices and that's what I help us out.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I just want to add a comment there because it enables us to repeat the 15 quarters in a row of EPS growth year-on-year has come under oil environments at $100 and oil environments at low $30. And there's been corrections out there because the vie
componenttext: Yes. And I just want to add a comment there because it enables us to repeat the 15 quarters in a row of EPS growth year-on-year has come under oil environments at $100 and oil environments at low $30. And there's been corrections out there because the view is that the basis of your question, Hassan, is that, in some way, where naphtha is versus ethane, where naphtha is versus propane, is linked to where oil is versus gas. And what we have seen and what Steve said and what we've now performed against under these diverse environments is, firstly, our geographic mix helps us. Secondly, our feedstock flexibility enables us. Thirdly, we've added to that flexibility, i.e. propane in Europe or a great example of that. We see propane as long as far as the eye can see. And lastly and very importantly, low oil price, over time, has enabled consumer demand. It took a while, but it's here. U.S. consumers are spending because they've got more money in their pockets. That's also happening in countries like China, which is becoming more consumer-led. So a low oil price with the enablement of feedstock on the Dow side, with ethane, propane, some butane, certainly in the U.S. and our feedstock in Europe means we can maximize profits in the chain that keeps slide that Jim has in his deck. We can make money as long as the demand -- there is demand. The feedstock input/output thing, we're managing to maximize profit maximize margins, which is a price volume trade-off in that chain. And we're doing it successfully now under oil environments.

componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd like to pick up on Hassan's question and go a little forward and been into the company's strong performance in the quarter. As [indiscernible] 15 quarters in a row, Consumer Solutions, Infrastructure Solutions and plastics performed, and they per
componenttext: Yes. I'd like to pick up on Hassan's question and go a little forward and been into the company's strong performance in the quarter. As [indiscernible] 15 quarters in a row, Consumer Solutions, Infrastructure Solutions and plastics performed, and they performed in tangent with a consumer-led economy. We have the portfolio to keep performing and keep strong performance, but we're not resting there. Self-help actions for the last many years on reducing costs, taking productivity to the bottom line, keeping it sticky. The 2,500 positions we're reducing, i.e. the 700 extra on top of the Dow Corning announcement is a great example of how we continue to work to the cost engine, not just feedstock, but actual costs, so that we can stay in the margin expansion mode, now 15 in a row. This is not only I know that margin but the working capital side of things. Given a look at what we've done. We produced 1 billion more pounds in the quarter from a year ago, 2 billion pounds more from the same machine from the first half point of view. Those extra pounds, and that's high operating rate, and disciplined working capital is generating this extra free cash flow that will feed the share buyback question that Howard answer. And we're very committed, working capital management, cash flow management, free cash flow generation to keep working the balance sheet so that we can increase your buybacks. And then the strong demand environment will continue. Look, it's not a great global economy, but it's a consumer-led economy and our product speak to it. And our new plants will come online at the right time. So all of our interventions are producing and continue to produce. Dow Corning, accretive in the first month synergies raise already. The merger on track, and with a great see-through to these 3 new entities, these 3 great growth entities. We're firing on all cylinders, and we will continue to do so.
