componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to The Dow Chemical Company's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Also, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Neal Sheorey. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to the Dow Chemical Company's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. I am Neal Sheorey, Vice President of Investor Relations. As usual, we are making this call available to investors and the media via webcast. This ca
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to the Dow Chemical Company's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. I am Neal Sheorey, Vice President of Investor Relations. As usual, we are making this call available to investors and the media via webcast. This call is the property of the Dow Chemical Company. Any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without Dow's express written consent is strictly prohibited. 
On the call with me today are Andrew Liveris, Dow's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Howard Ungerleider, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; and Jim Fitterling, President and Chief Operating Officer.
We have prepared slides to supplement our comments in this conference call. These slides are posted on our Investor Relations Financial Reporting page. You can also access the slides through the link to our webcast. 
I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in both the press release and in the slides. In summary, it says that statements in the press release, the presentation and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions under Federal Securities Laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we describe in our filings with the SEC. 
In addition, some of our comments reference non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure and other associated disclosures are contained in our earnings release and on our website. Unless otherwise specified, all comparisons presented today will be on a year-over-year basis. Sales comparisons exclude divestitures and acquisitions. EBITDA, EBITDA margin, return on capital and earnings comparisons exclude certain items.
Some of our comments may also contain statements about our announced agreement to complete a merger of equals with DuPont and the intention to subsequently spin into 3 independent, publicly traded companies. In connection with this intended transaction, Dow and DuPont have filed and will file materials with the SEC that contain important information. We advise you to read them. These filings are available, free of charge, from the SEC or Dow or DuPont, as applicable. 
I will now turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neal. And if everyone could turn to Slide 3. Good morning to everyone. The Dow team continues to deliver against every one of our goals for the year, building on our consistent track record of execution. Let's start with the financial highlig
componenttext:
Thank you, Neal. And if everyone could turn to Slide 3. Good morning to everyone. The Dow team continues to deliver against every one of our goals for the year, building on our consistent track record of execution. 
Let's start with the financial highlight. We achieved record third quarter EBITDA and our highest third quarter EPS in a decade. This quarter marked 4 full years, 16 consecutive quarters, of earnings growth and margin expansion. In addition, we returned more than $900 million of cash to our owners through stock buybacks and dividends. 
Operationally, we continue to meet consumer-led demand for Dow products and solution, driving volume gains in all geographies. We've now consistently grown volume over 3 years, 12 consecutive quarters, despite a slow-growth macro environment. 
We also delivered another quarter of productivity and cost savings, bringing the year-to-date contribution to $254 million, on track to exceed our 2016 target.
On our strategic projects, we accelerated the Dow Corning integration, moving quickly on our cost synergies, as we said we would. Our Sadara joint venture celebrated the startup of its multi-feed crackup and a third polyethylene train. And our next wave of U.S. Gulf Coast projects is on the cusp of delivering bottom line results. 
Dow's proven time and again the power and resilience of our business model, our focused market participation that shows resiliency in all environments, our commitment to self-help productivity and cost-cutting and the compelling upside from our strategic investments. Collectively, these drivers will deliver the next levels of earnings and cash flow growth and delivering that cash to our owners. 
I'll now turn the call over to Howard to discuss our financial performance, the Dow Corning integration, modeling guidance and our Ag results. Jim will cover the remaining businesses. And I'll close with some thoughts on our track record of success and our future growth trajectory. 
Howard?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. Turning to Slide 5. We had a number of important financial achievements in the quarter. We delivered operating EPS of $0.91, an 11% increase. We achieved record third quarter operating EBITDA of $2.5 billion,
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. 
Turning to Slide 5. We had a number of important financial achievements in the quarter. We delivered operating EPS of $0.91, an 11% increase. We achieved record third quarter operating EBITDA of $2.5 billion, up $118 million, and we expanded our operating EBITDA margin to 20%. Our earnings expansion was driven by our consumer-oriented businesses, which features strong results with the integration of Dow Corning and better-than-expected performance in Dow Ag. We grew volume in every geographic area in the quarter, with notable strength in Europe, which was up 9%; and the United States and China, both up 6%. Productivity continued to be an important contributor. We delivered another $76 million of savings in the quarter. And finally, we resumed our share buyback program, with more than $400 million of share repurchases in the quarter. 
Moving to Slide 6 and an update on Dow Corning. Since close, we have been working quickly to integrate the Silicones platform into our Consumer Solutions and Infrastructure Solutions businesses, as well as capturing the synergies. The quick wins we've already delivered underscore the power of the Silicones franchise, its highly complementary hand-in-glove fit with Dow's business model and the role this transaction plays in further enhancing our earnings growth profile.
First and foremost, the core business continues to outperform even our initial projections on broad-based volume gains and share growth. 
Second, I'm pleased to report that we've already reached more than $200 million in cost synergies on an annual run-rate basis. This was largely due to the value our team has extracted in purchasing, optimizing our warehouse and logistic footprints, as well as consolidating back-office operations.
We've also completed notifications with the vast majority of impacted roles, with only a small percentage remaining, where we're adhering to local labor rules. 
We remain on track to achieve a run rate of 70% against our $400 million cost synergy target by the first half of 2017 and 100% by the first half of '18. 
And finally, we're also seeing the power of Silicones on the growth side of the equation. As we've said for some time, Dow Corning Silicones is a natural fit into Dow's packaging, transportation, infrastructure and consumer care end markets. We are even more positive today about the growth synergy opportunities that this transaction presents. Our commercial and R&D teams finalized a playbook to achieve the $100 million growth synergy target, and in fact, we've already delivered some early cross-selling opportunities.
Bottom line, the Dow Corning integration is progressing very well, delivering financial returns, uncovering future growth opportunities and enhancing Dow's market-focused portfolio. 
Before we turn to our segment results, let me share some thoughts on modeling guidance on Slide 7.
In the fourth quarter, we expect ag market headwinds to persist, largely offset by our self-help actions. Comparing year-over-year, recall that we sold several nonstrategic molecules last year, which lifted Ag results in that period. 
Consumer Solutions will benefit from the integration of Dow Corning. Approximately 60% of Dow Corning's EBITDA and synergies are in this segment. We do expect typical seasonality in Electronic Materials and U.S. auto production as we approach year end. 
In Infrastructure Solutions, my comments about Dow Corning apply here as well, with the other 40% of its EBITDA generated here. This segment also consumes roughly 1/3 of the propylene from our PDH unit. We expect that to be offset by continued oil and gas headwinds in Energy & Water.
Turning to Performance Materials & Chemicals, which consumes 2/3 of the propylene from our PDH unit. From a seasonality standpoint, we could see some upside from deicer sales. After all, it did snow yesterday in Michigan. As you know, we have seen compression on the integrated EO and PO margins globally, which will impact PMC. Also, Sadara costs are increasing here as we continue to start up downstream units related to this segment. 
Finally, in Performance Plastics, we expect a modest uptick from the cracker and the 3 PE units at Sadara, as sales have begun. However, we expect these to be more than offset by higher costs from the Louisiana turnaround, debottleneck and maintenance activities currently underway, as well as higher feedstock cost globally.
Now let's turn to our segments. I'll start first with Ag on Slide 9 and then hand it to Jim to cover the rest of the businesses. 
Dow Ag continues to outperform despite the ongoing challenging industry fundamentals. Segment EBITDA increased by $141 million and represents the best third quarter result in nearly a decade. Several factors contributed to our success: Share gains due to continued increasing demand for our innovative products, price improvements, continued self-help actions and strong early demand for the Latin America growing season.
Latin America seeds was the highlight. Strong demand in the region drove record sales, with price and volume both rising by double digits. Corn seed sales nearly tripled, primarily on double-digit volume and price growth in Latin America. The business increased share, particularly in the Brazilian safrina season, where we have a strong position. Soybean sales nearly tripled as well, reflecting higher price and volume. 
Crop Protection set a third quarter EBITDA record, supported by improved product mix and ongoing self-help productivity and cost-cutting actions. Insecticides improved on increased price, while herbicide pricing and fungicide volume each declined. 
I'll now turn it over to Jim to cover the rest of our segments.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. Moving to Consumer Solutions on Slide 10. The segment achieved an all-time operating EBITDA record of $492 million, boosted by the integration of Dow Corning, which is further enhancing our end market positions across the segment. This
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. Moving to Consumer Solutions on Slide 10. The segment achieved an all-time operating EBITDA record of $492 million, boosted by the integration of Dow Corning, which is further enhancing our end market positions across the segment. This marks the fifth consecutive quarter of EBITDA growth for this segment, and it demonstrates the power and differentiation of our consumer, automotive and Electronic Materials franchises. 
Dow Automotive achieved its seventh consecutive quarter of EBITDA growth and a record third quarter EBITDA, led by double-digit volume gains in Asia Pacific on new business wins and market share gains. The business continues to grow above market on demand for Dow's light-weighting solution. 
Consumer Care grew market share through gains in homecare market sectors and new innovations for personal hygiene solutions. 
Silicones in the Consumer Solutions segment delivered double-digit volume growth in Asia Pacific behind demand for electronic and automotive applications. The business also achieved its first cross-selling opportunities with the Dow Automotive, Consumer Care and Polyurethanes businesses. 
And Dow Electronic Materials achieved record quarterly EBITDA. In addition to ongoing self-help measures, the business captured strong demand in semiconductor, interconnect and Display Technologies, particularly in Asia Pacific. 
On Slide 11, Infrastructure Solutions delivered EBITDA of $379 million, primarily reflecting the integration of Dow Corning. 
Dow Building & Construction achieved record third quarter EBITDA and delivered its eighth consecutive quarter of EBITDA growth. The business captured volume gains on demands for acrylic-based construction chemicals and benefited from continued voluntary adoption of our BLUEDGE polymeric flame retardant. 
Silicones in the Infrastructure Solutions segment reported volume and EBITDA growth, driven by improved demand in packaging and building construction applications. 
Dow Coating Materials reported volume growth in all market segments, led by strong demand in Asia Pacific and gains in both the architectural and industrial coatings sectors.
Moving to Slide 12. Performance and Materials Chemicals EBITDA declined, primarily due to the impact of portfolio actions, which included divestitures and the reduced ownership in MEGlobal, as well as higher Sadara startup cost. In the core business, pricing pressures led to unit margin compression, but this was partly offset by volume growth. 
In Polyurethanes, we achieved record volume on double-digit gains in specialty polyols and systems houses, led by growth in EMEA and Asia Pacific. 
Industrial Solutions reported volume gains in all businesses, also led by strength in EMEA and Asia Pacific.
Turning to Performance Plastics on Slide 13. The team achieved $1.25 billion of EBITDA and double-digit volume growth, with gains across all businesses. A key part of our continued success is the team's focus on manufacturing reliability and producing incremental volume in a robust demand environment.
Dow Packaging and Specialty Plastics delivered record third quarter sales volume on double-digit growth in developed geographies and adoption of new innovations for food and specialty packaging applications. 
Dow Elastomers also achieved record third quarter volume, driven by increasing global consumer preference for larger vehicles that incorporate more Dow content, as well as double-digit growth in athletic footwear. These applications are further enhanced by our innovative products, such as INTUNE and INFUSE olefin block copolymers.
Dow Electrical and Telecommunications reported double-digit volume gains in the Americas, as the business continues to benefit from the global trends toward fiber optic cabling for faster and more reliable wireless connections.
Additionally, Sadara started up its multi-feed cracker in August and a third polyethylene train in September, adding to the 2 polyethylene trains already in operation. 
In the U.S. Gulf Coast, we commenced the Louisiana turnaround and feedstock flexibility project. That unit will restart later this quarter, giving our LA-3 cracker the ability to produce an additional 250,000 tons per year of ethylene and enhancing the reliability of one of the best units in our fleet.
During the quarter, our Texas-9 ethylene facility has 85% mechanical completion, and we made significant progress on our Performance Plastics production facilities. Our target for Texas-9 to come online remains mid-2017.
And now I'll hand it back over to Andrew.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. If you'd turn to Slide 15. And there's a chart here that you should pay particular attention to, the one on the right of the slide. As I mentioned at the start of the call, we've now achieved for 4 full years, 16 consecutive quarters, of
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. If you'd turn to Slide 15. And there's a chart here that you should pay particular attention to, the one on the right of the slide. 
As I mentioned at the start of the call, we've now achieved for 4 full years, 16 consecutive quarters, of earnings growth and margin expansion. And we've been doing earnings growth now for over a decade. You can see that we have taken a series of purposeful steps taken over these past many years. These steps are deeply rooted in our strategy to get to the near term right and the long term right and steadfast execution from an aligned Team Dow. 
And to put things into context, you actually have to go back to the late 1990s, when our industry came under pressure from state-owned enterprises. Returns were clearly impacted because we all had, Dow included, a me-too product wheel. Low-cost integration was absolutely necessary, but on its own, not enough to ensure long-term profitable growth. 
Since then, we've taken a number of decisive actions to create a sustainable business model, building on both low-cost integration and innovation to drive our narrower and deeper focus in attractive end markets; to invest for growth in consumer-led sectors while having a strong presence in investment-driven markets, like infrastructure; and to control what we can control through disciplined productivity and cost saving. In doing so, we believe we've created a portfolio for all seasons, a more resilient portfolio, one built to grow and last. 
We have fundamentally shifted our earnings trajectory, not only enhancing our growth, but also driving greater consistency. Equally important, we have put in place a series of growth drivers that will serve us well in the near and long term. These include: A reinvigorated, industry-leading R&D engine which now delivers over 5,000 new products every year; a new set of technical capabilities, most notably the addition of Dow Corning Silicones; an expanded footprint in attractive global markets through our investments in the U.S. Gulf Coast, the Middle East and Asia, positioning us to grow where growth exists; and finally, a low-cost structure that has productivity wired into its very core. These drivers will further enhance our market focus, continue to reduce our volatility, bolster our integration and our innovation and ultimately maximize shareholder value creation.
Flipping to Slide 16. Of course, the ultimate proof of our business model is the enhanced returns Team Dow has delivered: Earnings growth, enhanced cash flow and higher shareholder returns. And going forward, our team remains relentlessly focused on our priorities: Delivering the operating and financial plan, accelerating earnings growth and value creation through the continued integration of Dow Corning and advancing through the DowDuPont transaction and intended wins. 
And we will do so despite persistent macro uncertainties. As I've said before, regional economic trends are mixed at best. North America and Europe show measured growth, with Dow products growing stronger than the market. Latin America, especially Brazil, which is beginning to recover, is a slow-growth environment. However, we do see bright spots there, particularly the Andean economies and Mexico. And economic transitions are underway in Asia, notably China. In this environment, we will continue to find growth where growth exists. That includes our core consumer-led markets of packaging, automotive and construction. 
As we establish the foundation for the new Dow, we have the right tools in hand to build the world's leading material science company. And our 4-year streak, 16 consecutive quarters, of earnings growth and margin expansion fuels our excitement for the future. 
In closing, on Slide 17, we have not, nor will we, lose sight of our priorities. Dow will continue to deliver through our focused portfolio, our integration, our innovation and our geographic reach, through our relentless focus on our execution and on maximizing value creation for our customers, for our shareholders, for the near term and for the long term. 
With that, Neal, let's turn it to Q&A.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

[Operator Instructions] 
And we'll take our first question from Frank Mitsch with Wells Fargo Security.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I look at the beats that you had and particularly the traffic volumes that you're seeing that we're not really hearing from a lot of other companies out there, and especially given the fact that 3 months ago, we probably weren't as optimistic as what t
componenttext: As I look at the beats that you had and particularly the traffic volumes that you're seeing that we're not really hearing from a lot of other companies out there, and especially given the fact that 3 months ago, we probably weren't as optimistic as what these results turned out to be, what exactly happened over the past 3 months to lead to this major upside?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start off, and I'll give it to Jim. At the end of the day, the volume is a harbinger of the product mix, Frank. There's no question that out there, consumer demand exists. I just come back in China. We -- I participated in a couple of interesting mar
componenttext: I'll start off, and I'll give it to Jim. At the end of the day, the volume is a harbinger of the product mix, Frank. There's no question that out there, consumer demand exists. I just come back in China. We -- I participated in a couple of interesting market-driven events, like Walmart had a food safety seminar. There is huge demand for safe food product supply in China. So that type of driver is actually growing double-digit, way above the Chinese economy. So where things are weak is in the industrial economy around the world. But where things are strong is safety drivers, hygiene drivers, environmental drivers and, actually, consumer drivers. And I think our product mix, especially with Dow Corning now added in, which has given us new growth synergies, is doubled down and tripled down on that part of the portfolio. And that's also true in packaging, in plastics, electrical and telecom and elastomers. Jim, did you want to add?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, in the weak spots, Andrew covered them. In oil and gas, although we've seen a little bit of rebound in the energy sector, it's not enough yet to have a significant impact in Industrial Solutions. Industrial Solutions has got weakness in oil a
componenttext: I would say, in the weak spots, Andrew covered them. In oil and gas, although we've seen a little bit of rebound in the energy sector, it's not enough yet to have a significant impact in Industrial Solutions. Industrial Solutions has got weakness in oil and gas, steel, industrial coatings applications for steel and also some EO Derivatives in the Ag space. And in Latin America, really, Brazil is the story. Our sales in Latin America are good, but Brazil's at bottom and trying to recover right now. Otherwise, the rest of the businesses had strong volume performance and strong demand: North America, Europe, China, Southeast Asia. And a little softness in the Middle East because of what's going on with the oil economy.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next I'll move to David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next I'll move to David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, another strong quarter in plastics. As we head into 2017 and the startup of a number of ethylene crackers, and even '18, what's your view on U.S. ethylene chain margin in 2017?
componenttext: Andrew, another strong quarter in plastics. As we head into 2017 and the startup of a number of ethylene crackers, and even '18, what's your view on U.S. ethylene chain margin in 2017?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, why don't you take that one?
componenttext: Jim, why don't you take that one?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, I think the startup of the crackers is going to be staged over 2017. So our view is you're going to see, obviously from our perspective, some uptick in our sales growth because we've got 3 new trains from Sadara running now. We'll have a fourt
componenttext: Yes, David, I think the startup of the crackers is going to be staged over 2017. So our view is you're going to see, obviously from our perspective, some uptick in our sales growth because we've got 3 new trains from Sadara running now. We'll have a fourth one coming up in first quarter in Sadara. And then mid-2017, we've got our Gulf Coast projects coming on. So I think from our perspective, we've been running the franchise flat out for this last 12 months, and inventories are at 5-year lows in the downstream chain. So our view is the market demand, as long as you don't have a cataclysmic event in the economy, the market demand is going to be there for these products. And the timing of these start-ups is going to be such that I don't think you're going to see it really loosen up that much next year.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And bottom line is everyone's expectations of a very weak ethylene market in 2017, in our view, are way too pessimistic. We're already seeing delays. And notably, our 3 PE units started tup in Sadara are running flat out. And so it's a harbinger of strong
componenttext: And bottom line is everyone's expectations of a very weak ethylene market in 2017, in our view, are way too pessimistic. We're already seeing delays. And notably, our 3 PE units started tup in Sadara are running flat out. And so it's a harbinger of strong demand drivers, especially the areas Jim and I have referred to already, Dave.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we move on to Steve Byrne with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next, we move on to Steve Byrne with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttextpreview: Continuing on this ethylene chain margin discussion, how would you characterize the feedstock mix in your ethylene crackers right now? How does that compare to where it's been the last couple of years? And more importantly, where do you see it going over
componenttext: Continuing on this ethylene chain margin discussion, how would you characterize the feedstock mix in your ethylene crackers right now? How does that compare to where it's been the last couple of years? And more importantly, where do you see it going over the next couple of years?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Jim.
componenttext: Go ahead, Jim.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our mix right now is still light. So obviously, ethane and propane both in the mix. And it just depends on what part of the world you're in, what's in and what particular week. But that still looks good. Obviously, what you've seen through the course o
componenttext: So our mix right now is still light. So obviously, ethane and propane both in the mix. And it just depends on what part of the world you're in, what's in and what particular week. But that still looks good. Obviously, what you've seen through the course of this year is our naphtha-based units become more competitive. So you're seeing good equity earnings out of our Thai joint ventures. You've seen our positions in Europe become stronger over the last couple of years. I think that continues to play out. Our view is that propane is still long, and propane is Dow's big advantage in feedstock flexibility. Propane is still long for some time to come. Ethane is still long until you get to the end of all these projects coming on, which is more like the '19, '20 time frame. So our view is we're still going to see some very good margin -- chain margins in this space.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan will have a question.
componenttext: And next, Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan will have a question.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your Performance Plastics discussion for the fourth quarter, you framed things year-over-year. And last year, in Performance Plastics, you made about $1.3 billion in EBITDA, and it looks like you seem to say that you're going to be flat to down, which
componenttext: In your Performance Plastics discussion for the fourth quarter, you framed things year-over-year. And last year, in Performance Plastics, you made about $1.3 billion in EBITDA, and it looks like you seem to say that you're going to be flat to down, which would be sort of roughly a flat performance in the fourth quarter from the third quarter, even though propylene prices are up and polyethylene prices are up. Regionally, where are you feeling a squeeze? And is this a correct characterization of your guidance?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Jim.
componenttext: Go ahead, Jim.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, Jeff, the difference I would say is we've got turnarounds in this quarter that are fairly significant. So the Louisiana 3 turnaround, the majority of that cost comes in this quarter. And we expect that unit to be up some time mid-November. Th
componenttext: I would say, Jeff, the difference I would say is we've got turnarounds in this quarter that are fairly significant. So the Louisiana 3 turnaround, the majority of that cost comes in this quarter. And we expect that unit to be up some time mid-November. That is not just a turnaround, but it's also tying in the ethylene -- the ethane cracking flexibility, which is both front-end on the furnaces and back-end on the distillation section and separation section of the plant. So that's a big turnaround. You still got Sadara startup costs for another polyethylene that comes -- train that comes up in first quarter. So those are neither one in last year. The other example I would give you is, when you look at this quarter and third quarter, if you look at the margin compression year-over-year, half of that is from Sadara startup costs and the beginning of the LA-3 turnaround. So I don't we're foretelling that there's a big margin compression coming here or there's big drop-off in demand. I think it's really more related to one-off items. We've also been doing turnarounds in our polyethylene derivatives space. So in Seadrift, where we're heavy on electrical and telecom capacity, we've been doing some turnarounds and debottlenecks and reliability work there. We're doing the similar types of things in St. Charles in our LP-6 plant. We're getting ready for, really, the Texas-9 cracker coming up and the ability to have more ethylene down in the Gulf Coast and get as much as we can out of the franchise in the Gulf Coast.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll move on to PJ Juvekar with Citi.
componenttext: And next, we'll move on to PJ Juvekar with Citi.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You have significant investments coming online in the Gulf Coast, Sadara. You got Texas-9 PDH. When you look at all this, how much impairment in EBITDA do you expect from all these investments? And if you -- if there is a potential downturn, let's say, in
componenttext: You have significant investments coming online in the Gulf Coast, Sadara. You got Texas-9 PDH. When you look at all this, how much impairment in EBITDA do you expect from all these investments? And if you -- if there is a potential downturn, let's say, in 2018, '19, using this incremental EBITDA can offset any ethylene downturn?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, why don't you take the first part of that question on EBITDA forecasting?
componenttext: Howard, why don't you take the first part of that question on EBITDA forecasting?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I mean, I think you have to go back and you have to have a view of whether you're a bull or a bear in this cycle. I mean, we put out a long-term range in 2014 at the Investor Day, and we said, "Look all of these projects add at least $3 billion
componenttext: Yes. Well, I mean, I think you have to go back and you have to have a view of whether you're a bull or a bear in this cycle. I mean, we put out a long-term range in 2014 at the Investor Day, and we said, "Look all of these projects add at least $3 billion of EBITDA over the long term." I mean, so that -- and we're still standing by that number. That's a long-term number, and when you add it all up, that's where we see the long term.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jim, on the ethylene part?
componenttext: And Jim, on the ethylene part?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so P.J., when we authorized all of these investments, we said we expected greater than $3 billion of EBITDA impact out of all of them. And as Howard said, at any point in time, you can have some cash margins there above or below where we are right no
componenttext: Yes, so P.J., when we authorized all of these investments, we said we expected greater than $3 billion of EBITDA impact out of all of them. And as Howard said, at any point in time, you can have some cash margins there above or below where we are right now. PDH today, case in point, St. Charles was right on the line with what we said. PDH today is still running very positive cash margins, even in a low propylene environment is running very positive cash margins. LA-3, the real EBITDA incremental from LA-3 is the fact you get 250,000 [ph] tons a year more ethylene out of that. So that's right to our bottom line. That's produced for us versus purchased. So that goes to the bottom line. And Texas 9 and derivatives is a whole new slate of products. It's really 4 of our highest value-add derivatives plants on that franchise. It's our highest growing segments of your going to continue to ship the mix year up in the higher-performing products and away from the most commoditized parts of earnings. So we're still bullish on the fact that we're going to deliver these results.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to get it out now, I know you guys are all into the plastics forecast here. This company, the next slide I did in the deck shows consistent earnings growth with the plastics profile having obviously a good effect, but it doesn't wobble the compan
componenttext: And just to get it out now, I know you guys are all into the plastics forecast here. This company, the next slide I did in the deck shows consistent earnings growth with the plastics profile having obviously a good effect, but it doesn't wobble the company as much as it used to because of the value-add that Jim finished on. Plus, the forecast going forward on supply side shows more of a plateau in these next few years despite the supply adds because of the delays. So we think high operating environments and strong value-add demand drivers like packaging, EMC and Elastomers builds margin for Dow from here, not destroys margin. After that, the feedstock flexibility point on the previous question, that's an expanding margin scenario in one of our core franchises.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we move on to Jonas Oxgaard with Bernstein.
componenttext: And next we move on to Jonas Oxgaard with Bernstein.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at Sadara, in your numbers, you said 80 million pounds sold. If my math is right, that's about a 10% of the utilization. Looking at next quarter, everything is running full out. Does that mean you'll reach somewhere around 90% utilization on the a
componenttext: Looking at Sadara, in your numbers, you said 80 million pounds sold. If my math is right, that's about a 10% of the utilization. Looking at next quarter, everything is running full out. Does that mean you'll reach somewhere around 90% utilization on the actual plant? And how should I think about the EBITDA or the JV income contribution from this?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just to be very clear, we have 4 units running of the 24 that have to start up. And so we got a fair while to go before we get up on the utilization rate for the whole complex. The 4 units that are running, clearly, the 3 polyethylene trains are r
componenttext: Yes. So just to be very clear, we have 4 units running of the 24 that have to start up. And so we got a fair while to go before we get up on the utilization rate for the whole complex. The 4 units that are running, clearly, the 3 polyethylene trains are running flat out. That was the point we're making earlier. So we are very early in the capacity utilization. We still expect reliability test in 2018 time frame. But 2017 is going to be a big startup year for us. However, the headwind will start becoming more tailwind, and I'll give that part it to Howard.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jonas. Good morning. I would say, look, in the fourth quarter, we will have a tailwind in plastics versus Sadara but offset by the comments that Jim made relative to Louisiana 3 turnaround and some of the higher costs coming globally from a feedstock
componenttext: Yes, Jonas. Good morning. I would say, look, in the fourth quarter, we will have a tailwind in plastics versus Sadara but offset by the comments that Jim made relative to Louisiana 3 turnaround and some of the higher costs coming globally from a feedstock standpoint. But 2017, it will definitely be a tailwind for plastics, but as Andrew said, you still have 22 units that you're in the steep part of that curve in spending. And those are all in PNC, with the exception of one additional polyolefins unit that'll start up in the first quarter. So PMC will be a headwind all through 2017.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we'll move to Duffy Fischer with Barclays.
componenttext: And next we'll move to Duffy Fischer with Barclays.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to go back to the volume number in the Performance Plastics segment, and I was wondering if you could talk about it may be in 3 buckets. So how much of that volume improvement was your existing asset base that just ran harder so in the olefin side
componenttext: Wanted to go back to the volume number in the Performance Plastics segment, and I was wondering if you could talk about it may be in 3 buckets. So how much of that volume improvement was your existing asset base that just ran harder so in the olefin side this quarter? How much was new olefins capacity that debottlenecks or some of the new plants coming online? And then how much was the downstream value-added where you're able to upgrade those olefins into capacity that wasn't utilized a year ago?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, we don't think of it that way, but I think we'll give you a stat. Go ahead.
componenttext: Jim, we don't think of it that way, but I think we'll give you a stat. Go ahead.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just high level, Duffy, it was the first that you mentioned, existing asset base. I said before, we've been running flat out sold-out in those units. We've achieved some pretty phenomenal operating unit rates in those units in spite of the fact that we've
componenttext: Just high level, Duffy, it was the first that you mentioned, existing asset base. I said before, we've been running flat out sold-out in those units. We've achieved some pretty phenomenal operating unit rates in those units in spite of the fact that we've turned a few of them around in this year to get ready for the Texas-9 startup. And then I would say the rest of it is the latter part. The mix shift and the value-add from the mix shift is the big thing. There really hasn't been enough time to have enough of an impact from new capacity. As Sadara starts up, you've got to fill that supply chain to get the product out, so we've been moving a lot of the product out into that supply chain. We sold some the material, as was discussed earlier, in the third quarter and the month of September. However, you're going to see more of those sales come in in the fourth quarter as we get 3 units running and we're getting that supply chain full. And for that reason, a lot of our growth in the third quarter was North America, Europe and then China and Southeast Asia. And I would say, had we had more Sadara volume in the third quarter, we'd have had more growth in China.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of the investment we've done in the machine, the assets the last many years, has now made that machine more reliable. So our production is up versus the same quarter last year, up 9%. That's 1.9 billion pounds that we've sold in Q3 that we didn't se
componenttext: A lot of the investment we've done in the machine, the assets the last many years, has now made that machine more reliable. So our production is up versus the same quarter last year, up 9%. That's 1.9 billion pounds that we've sold in Q3 that we didn't sell a year ago. Year-to-date, that number is 5.6 billion pounds. So kudos to our operations people. They're running safely. They're running reliably. And our sales people have been able to get it out the door and move more volume to demand based on value-add and, therefore, kept inventories quite low. So this machine is moving into the high 80s operating rate, right now, at 86%, as a totality of Dow, not just at the integration piece that I'm referring. I'm talking about the whole company. And so the value-add piece, when you think about innovation agenda, stretches across all of it, from the propylene derivatives, to the ethylene derivatives, to the silicones derivatives, all the value-add piece. And very few of our businesses today are reselling the strict monomer. Probably the last remaining example of that is our acrylic chains, our performers polymer, where we are moving, riding all those monomers down to Goliad polymers and promotions. That's the last part of the Dow commodity engine that self-interest commodities.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next will move on to Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And next will move on to Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question that we've had some increases in the oil price more recently. And I guess, as I'm thinking about kind of what's left of this year and into next year and we think about the ethylene and polyethylene chain, can you anticipate those higher pr
componenttext: Just a question that we've had some increases in the oil price more recently. And I guess, as I'm thinking about kind of what's left of this year and into next year and we think about the ethylene and polyethylene chain, can you anticipate those higher prices increasing the marginal costs of production and flowing through to product prices such as you can hold on to the recent $0.05 increase in polyethylene prices? Or should we expect seasonality and everything else to overwhelm that?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the last defines it, but I'll let Jim get into the detail. But in essence, there's always a lead lag factor. But as oil prices go up, that's generally good for us over time. But there is always transitions. Jim, speak to it, please..
componenttext: I think the last defines it, but I'll let Jim get into the detail. But in essence, there's always a lead lag factor. But as oil prices go up, that's generally good for us over time. But there is always transitions. Jim, speak to it, please..

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's generally good. I mean, gas, the feedstock for us is predominantly gas. And so what you see is it's remained low and steady for this time period. And so we haven't seen any real move-up in the input costs. We saw prices firm up in polyethylene at the
componenttext: It's generally good. I mean, gas, the feedstock for us is predominantly gas. And so what you see is it's remained low and steady for this time period. And so we haven't seen any real move-up in the input costs. We saw prices firm up in polyethylene at the end of third quarter, and we've seen them firm into the beginning of fourth quarter. And I think that's back to inventories being low and demand being high. And so as oil goes up, that just as an element to prices being able to firm up in the near term. And that's our view, and I'll stop at trying to predict what's going to happen with oil price. But at least that's where we are today in the current quarter.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll move to Peter Butler with Glenhill Investment.
componenttext: Next we'll move to Peter Butler with Glenhill Investment.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Management appears to be making really good progress improving the quality, consistency and predictability of the earnings stream. Would this encourage Dow's board to significantly boost the dividend payout ratio and boost the share repurchase program? It
componenttext: Management appears to be making really good progress improving the quality, consistency and predictability of the earnings stream. Would this encourage Dow's board to significantly boost the dividend payout ratio and boost the share repurchase program? It also could cause analysts to boost Dow's trend earnings growth projections in their models.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Howard.
componenttext: Go ahead, Howard.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, and good morning, Peter. Thanks for noticing about the consistency and the increasing results. I appreciate it. Look, on the dividend and share repurchase, we've been on a streak here of a double-digit CAGR of growing our dividend for the las
componenttext: Yes, thanks, and good morning, Peter. Thanks for noticing about the consistency and the increasing results. I appreciate it. Look, on the dividend and share repurchase, we've been on a streak here of a double-digit CAGR of growing our dividend for the last several years. Our payout ratio really hasn't changed. It's a 45% of net income target, long-term target that will go back to the shareholders in the form of dividend growth. And we've been tracking that number as the earnings have improved, net income has improved, we've improved the dividend. On stock buyback, the same. I mean, we spent over $7 billion of cash in the last several years buying back stock. You saw that the enter the market again. Now that the shareholder vote was behind us on the DowDuPont transaction, we bought more than $400 million worth of stock back in the third quarter, with about $1.9 billion left in our open program. And so we're going to continue to do that as well.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, look, I've said it many times in these calls and between calls, the last many years has been a proof point that we can be a consistent cash flow generator and earnings grower so we can return cash to owners. And that'll come through dividends
componenttext: Yes, I mean, look, I've said it many times in these calls and between calls, the last many years has been a proof point that we can be a consistent cash flow generator and earnings grower so we can return cash to owners. And that'll come through dividends and share buybacks while we fund our growth programs. We're coming off some pretty significant investment on CapEx here. And so as we come off that CapEx spend, that's going to open up more to cash flow. If we think we're undervalued, which we do, we'll buy back shares. And if we go back to our board for more authorization. But for sure, the consistent dividend grower is part of the Dow mix of returning money to our owners.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next I'll move on to John Roberts with UBS.
componenttext: And next I'll move on to John Roberts with UBS.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You announced you're divesting a small ethylene copolymers business, which I assume overlapped with DuPont's packaging polymer businesses as related to the antitrust issues. I know the Ag antitrust continues, but have you largely concluded the antitrust d
componenttext: You announced you're divesting a small ethylene copolymers business, which I assume overlapped with DuPont's packaging polymer businesses as related to the antitrust issues. I know the Ag antitrust continues, but have you largely concluded the antitrust discussions outside of Ag?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So complex regulatory processes in EU, China and particularly in the U.S., those 3 in particular, but Brazil remained in front of us in terms of whatever might come from them. We clearly have been in the market on the ethylene acrylic acid copolymers and
componenttext: So complex regulatory processes in EU, China and particularly in the U.S., those 3 in particular, but Brazil remained in front of us in terms of whatever might come from them. We clearly have been in the market on the ethylene acrylic acid copolymers and business under the [indiscernible] brand. That is one that we have foreshadowed. We have no surprises any of the discussions. They are going in the longer than we had hoped. As Ed, I think, said on his call, we expect Q1 close. We're already confident about that. We're not in a position to speak to specific revenues. We are waiting for those key jurisdictions. Just a note by the way, we've got 10 approvals already, and jurisdictions have approved us, some pretty key ones as well. However, having said that, setting the pace here through EC, DOJ, MOFCOM is our whole focus. And we're being very, very thoughtful about how to respond over time. You're going to some filings from time to time, especially out DC. I think is important to note that their process does that. Just know that we're quite aware of all of that, and we are working towards -- a few months shouldn't impact the value creation of a $30 billion deal. But taking a few months, you should want us to all do that.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll move to Hassan Ahmed with Alembic Global.
componenttext: Next we'll move to Hassan Ahmed with Alembic Global.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, through the course of the couple of months, we've seen some fairly significant moves up in coal prices, right? Now as you sort of sit there and think through sort of the macro, call it, ethylene, polyethylene pricing environment, do you see sort o
componenttext: Andrew, through the course of the couple of months, we've seen some fairly significant moves up in coal prices, right? Now as you sort of sit there and think through sort of the macro, call it, ethylene, polyethylene pricing environment, do you see sort of these moves having an impact, first and foremost, on sort of ethylene and polyethylene pricing? And secondly, do you see them having any sort of impact on future, call it, CTO, MTO, CTP supply?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I mentioned earlier, I'm going to give the part of the question to Jim here in a second. But just on the big energy picture as it relates to China, in particular, I was just over there as I indicated. I would tell you, China is deindustrializing ver
componenttext: So as I mentioned earlier, I'm going to give the part of the question to Jim here in a second. But just on the big energy picture as it relates to China, in particular, I was just over there as I indicated. I would tell you, China is deindustrializing very fast, Hassan. I have no confidence that they're going to allocate capital to coal or emissions heavy investments. I think there will be some of that but these are massive capital investments that have the problem of not being forecastable in terms of returns, and that's the other point. I believe certain enterprises got this from, literally, the top leadership under huge pressure to show returns. And they are having, in essence, a [indiscernible] moment in terms of understanding how capital gets allocated between equity, property and other investments. It's much more western financial environment appearing there, especially as they open up the financial sector, which there pretty much are committing to do. I think that recalibration in China is going to slow down coal heavy investments in time. The paradox there is a think they're going to much heavier in the nuclear. I think that's going to be their place of choice while they transition to LNG. So I'm not comfortable and all that you're going to see CTO or MTO off of coal coming in any way near the pace that was foreshadowed. Jim, on the margin investments?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing that I would add to what Andrew said is most of the capacity at on those CTO and MTO plays is heavily, heavily commodity-oriented C4. And is not really an area that we play and significantly in that part of the world or really anywhere righ
componenttext: The only thing that I would add to what Andrew said is most of the capacity at on those CTO and MTO plays is heavily, heavily commodity-oriented C4. And is not really an area that we play and significantly in that part of the world or really anywhere right now. So we're shifted towards a much higher mix, more driven towards the end use markets that we talked about before. We still think, and we have thought for a lot of the people are pretty optimistic about the rate at which these plants are that and how high they're going to run. And there's this is fast the satisfaction already in terms of returns on all these investments heavily, heavily capital-intensive to put in one of these operations relative to what you can do in the U.S. Gulf Coast or in the Middle East.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Christopher Parkinson with Credit Suisse will have our next question.
componenttext: And Christopher Parkinson with Credit Suisse will have our next question.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that was an Ag that seeds checking a lot on the back of Latin American demand on both price and volume. But can you just comment a little more about the key drivers here and a little more on your expectations heading into [indiscernible] as
componenttext: You mentioned that was an Ag that seeds checking a lot on the back of Latin American demand on both price and volume. But can you just comment a little more about the key drivers here and a little more on your expectations heading into [indiscernible] as well as prebuying in the U.S.? And also, you mentioned Crop Protection was negative. I'm assuming most of that was insecticides in Brazil, but were there also challenges in Europe as well?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Howard.
componenttext: Go ahead, Howard.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris, so overall on the key drivers, I mean, really proud of the Dow Ag team in the quarter. I mean, $141 million improvement versus I break down the drivers into 3 buckets, and it was pretty much equally split. About 1/3 was due to the higher volum
componenttext: Yes, Chris, so overall on the key drivers, I mean, really proud of the Dow Ag team in the quarter. I mean, $141 million improvement versus I break down the drivers into 3 buckets, and it was pretty much equally split. About 1/3 was due to the higher volumes and higher prices and specifically, seed in Brazil for sure. About 1/3 came from just the continued drumbeat, steady drumbeat now, for many quarters in a row on self-help productivity and cost-cutting. And then the other 1/3 was really by the turnaround in currency if you think about a year ago, there were pretty big currency headwinds facing loss in Ag, and it didn't help much. Actually, in the quarter, actually, I think it was 1 percentage point of the price up was related to currency in Ag. And the company level, currency was 0 help to us. But it helped on the margin, and certainly, the delta changed. That was the other 1/3 of the key drivers. I mean, when you think about why the volume was up in seeds in Brazil, I would say a couple of things: one, just the continued development of our new technologies that we continue to introduce, that farmers continue to get more and more comfortable that it does what it says, and it increases their yield. And so they just continued to get used to it. I do think there was some early buying in the quarter. I mean, the farmers, we don't get to choose the weather, the farmers decide when they get the plant, and I do think there was some of that. That will be a Q3 versus a Q4 move. So I would not count all of that as a Q3 gain. But we feel good about where we ended up in the quarter.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next we'll move to Robert Koort with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: You're next we'll move to Robert Koort with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, was wondering, you mentioned oil and gas, maybe some signs of life. Is that more things flattening? Or are you actually seeing an uptick? And can also just give us in your deck, that shows the polyethylene, ethylene long-term supply-demand balance, w
componenttext: Jim, was wondering, you mentioned oil and gas, maybe some signs of life. Is that more things flattening? Or are you actually seeing an uptick? And can also just give us in your deck, that shows the polyethylene, ethylene long-term supply-demand balance, what your growth rates for both are assumed in those charts?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on oil, Bob, really, we've seen a flattening and kind of an uptick here in the U.S., which I think is it's instructive that $50 a barrel, you got people moving rigs back in the oil production down in the Gulf Coast. It hasn't been a lot. Remember,
componenttext: Yes, so on oil, Bob, really, we've seen a flattening and kind of an uptick here in the U.S., which I think is it's instructive that $50 a barrel, you got people moving rigs back in the oil production down in the Gulf Coast. It hasn't been a lot. Remember, 1,500 rigs were moved out of production, and you've got about 11 to 15 that are moved back in. But it is a move, and it's starting that direction so there is cautious optimizing there. I think as -- if prices continue to firm up on oil, they continue to firm up toward the $55, maybe even next year into the $60 range, you're going to see more rigs coming back in. So gas is going to be competitive. Some of these fields can be competitive at $25 a barrel. So I think we've got a situation, which is good for us that the U.S. is competitive, and it's going to be there longer. And so when you look at where our assets are around the world, it's a very good competitive cost positions basis to have our franchise. As far as supply-demand balance is and the numbers that are in here, we're still running at the traditional 1 3 [ph], 1 4x GDP types of numbers for demand, and the real question mark is what's the GDP number that you plug into there. I would say the beginning of the year, we were starting with something like a 3% global GDP, and we've backed off of that some through the year, more towards goal of 2.5% number. But look, we've had 6% growth all year, and we've also had between 6% and 10% in China year-over-year. We operated in kind of the 4% range in North America, similar, maybe a little bit stronger in Europe and kind of flat in Latin America. So our view going forward is these operating rates are strong, and it's not just reflective of the fact that you've got the historical rates. It's also sustainable packaging is driving a lot of transitory plastics, and that's competing against other materials, and we're not getting materials out. So I think the sustainability trends are helping us stay there.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll hear from Don Carson with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Next we'll hear from Don Carson with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, a question on Ag antitrust approvals. Your strong Ag results, I think, underscore your underappreciated Brazilian currency position. You actually got a bigger share there than DuPont. So wondering if overlapping seed is an issue in South America.
componenttext: Andrew, a question on Ag antitrust approvals. Your strong Ag results, I think, underscore your underappreciated Brazilian currency position. You actually got a bigger share there than DuPont. So wondering if overlapping seed is an issue in South America. And then more broadly, how do you address that nonproduct overlap issues? The EC has made some raising concerns about potentially reduced innovation due to decline in R&D spending as you combined. And then how do you put your deal in the context of the other 2 transactions going on, which the regulars have said they'll also look at as well?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don. I mean, you have to start where you were leaving off. I mean, as I mentioned many times already on this call that food and agriculture, discussions for countries and regions, but just like energy and just like security, food is right at th
componenttext: Thank you, Don. I mean, you have to start where you were leaving off. I mean, as I mentioned many times already on this call that food and agriculture, discussions for countries and regions, but just like energy and just like security, food is right at the centerpiece of critical, basically, making sure that the constituencies are satisfied, that they have adequate and safe food supply. So agricultural lobbies and farm lobbies are strong everywhere, and of course, great unlevel playing field around the world. That's why some jurisdictions will have GMOs and some with GMOs. There's some jurisdictions that have trade protection barriers and some that don't. So this is not a new conversation. Eyes wide open going to our transaction, as you all know, you in particular, about 10 years of asking the question, what are you going to do with Ag? We always felt that there was a complementarity between biology and chemistry and integrated farm science helping the farmers. Integrated farm science, including Big Data, is expensive. And R&D to fuel that has to be funded in a public company over long cycles. In short-cycle investment thesis, many people have patient money for long-cycle investment. The smart scale of innovation and procompetitiveness for farmers to get the very best out of their plot of line, whether it's an acre or 10,000 acres, raw crops and niche crops and the sites needed to get more food, safe, reliable food to all the citizens of those countries, it is the mission at hand with our deal. And frankly, I'm sure it's the mission with other deals. We are first in all jurisdictions. We are very eyes wide open on what it means to create a procompetitive farm lobby, and we believe our deal does that. And if there are pushbacks based on various views on how those innovations come to market, we will definitely engage and are engaging. Again, we are taking the time to listen very carefully to what the jurisdictions want us to do, and we are very, very thoughtful on those remedies and we are confident will close this deal in Q1 and, frankly, sold that complex equation that you asked about a globally, of particular or not.

We bought back, I think I mentioned earlier, over $7 billion worth of stock year in the last several years and another $400 million. We're planning to continue to do that. So we're working the equation both ways, and you should continue to expect that.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So on Sadara startup costs, right now, we're in the EO and derivatives and getting ready for the [indiscernible] signage block, which is 9 integrated units in that block to star tup. And that'll be first quarter, second quarter, third quarter types o
componenttext: Yes. So on Sadara startup costs, right now, we're in the EO and derivatives and getting ready for the [indiscernible] signage block, which is 9 integrated units in that block to star tup. And that'll be first quarter, second quarter, third quarter types of timing for those things. So you expect to see that through next year. And that's a significant number of units. And then once you get to 2018, you'll see those startup cost away and will be back to having the full units up and operational. At the same time, on the ground in Sadara, within the joint venture, they're working hard to get their cost positions where it needs to be and get their comps where they need to be to be competitive as a JV in their own right. So I think both of those things are going to have an impact to 2018. I already said, we expect plastics to show positive next year. We expect it still to be a headwind and Industrial Solutions and Performance Materials, but we're working through all that right now.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think the issue is where we're playing in automotive. When you look at the number of applications that we're in, whether it's our plastics products, engaged things like bumper for the cars, our lightweighting solutions like our crash durable adh
componenttext: Yes. So I think the issue is where we're playing in automotive. When you look at the number of applications that we're in, whether it's our plastics products, engaged things like bumper for the cars, our lightweighting solutions like our crash durable adhesives. So as companies continue to use carbon fiber, aluminum, other things, to bond to the steel frames, they need for adhesives in that the goal. And when you get to it, we look at content per vehicle. So even though, in some areas, production in automotive year-over-year has flattened out, we're expanding our content per vehicle in that space, and I think that's what's driving the growth for us. Elastomers is a big product line that sells a lot into the automotive sector. Coatings as well into areas like sound dampening for the car is an area that people sometimes don't appreciate how much content goes into the automotive space. So that's how we're growing better than market is really getting the content per vehicle up and getting the number of solutions on the new vehicles up. And as you go into the heavier vehicles, in trucks, you get into crossovers and higher-performing vehicles like the higher-performing sedan, the ones that people more value for, we have more content on those vehicles then say the entry-level sedan.

componenttext: I kind of want to wrap the call by, one more time, referring to the visuals we showed you on Slide 15 and 16, which showed the CAGR of 6% on the earnings growth and EBITDA growth. I also showed what we've done cash flow and we've done on the TSR. I would tell you that, again, controlling what we can't control, self-help and productivity and innovation agenda speaks to that last question a bit, which is why we're going volumes above market. We're growing where growth is needed, and we have built a portfolio, really, under all sorts of environments that can perform, a portfolio for all seasons. We're very focused here on running the business through its maximum EBITDA EPS output. At the same time, we're very focused on closing the DowDuPont deal, and we're powering those things. I'm very proud of our team and that we've been able to do both. There's never been a better time at Dow. We're better positioned than ever before. We have a strong track record multiple years now of delivering and we're delivering these results under these macros that, frankly, are not very helpful. But we have the portfolio, and we've built the business. And you can expect us to return cash to our owners. That's our focus. And this value-creation of the deal in front of us who wants to close the deal on implement the synergies and get going on the  spins, we'll create a more value for our owners. So I really want to double down on the fact, this is a company that's delivering, and we will continue to do so.
